You can convert the red phosporus into white phosporus by distilling it in an atmosphere of carbon dioxide and condense it under water. It looks like melted candle wax.
for a phosphorus-free route, wikipedia says Iodomethane can also be prepared by the reaction of methanol with aqueous hydrogen iodide

I suppose homologs from the appropriate alcohols, e.g. ethanol=iodoethane QA, n-propanol=1- iodoopropane, 1+phenylethane-2-ol=
1-iodo-2-phenylethane, etc.
Analogous with bromine =
bromoalkanes? With bromomethane of course, there's the volatility to deal with (I used to have a 5 gallon bucket with ice water and a marine bilge pump for recirculation - great for high vapor pressure solvents and saving water).
People should know haloalkanes are, well, alkylating agents - risk of DNA damage among many other deleterious effects. In fact, bromomethane was used as an agricultural fumigant for many years...haloalkanes are also ozone depleters....who knew?
Wanna hear a strange haloalkane story? Check out
dichloropropane and 1,3-dichloropropene mixtures were also used as soil fumigants....until they noticed that the mixture caused male sterility.

Will you make dimethyl Mercury? It is a highly volatile, reactive, flammable, and colorless liquid, it's also one of the strongest known neurotoxins, with a quantity of less than 0.1 mL capable of inducing severe mercury poisoning. Dimethyl Mercury is easily absorbed through skin, and can cross the human blood brain barrier.
Methyl Iodide is also used in geology for separating minerals.

Use it to synthesize the methyl ester of a  carboxyic acid and form an amide from the methyl ester directly. IE: subsituted carboxylic acid (3mmol), K2CO3 (0.6g) and CH3I (0.6g, 4.4 mmol) in acetone (51mL) stirred at reflux overnight. Sovent removrd in vacuo, water( 20 mL) added to residue, extract wirh DCM(3×20mL), dried over MgSO4, and solvent removed in vacuo to yield ester as an oil (97.4% est. Yield). Without purification, a mixture of the ester (3.9 mmol), NH4Cl(5.3 mmol) and conc. NH4OH (20 mL) and MeOH( 5.7 mL) stirred at 50°C for 72 h. MeOH reduced in vacuo and rxn mixture dilited with water (50 mL), extracred with ethyl acetate (3×50mL), and dried over MgSO4. Solvent reduced in vacuo to afford crude product which is purified via flash column chromatography to give prod.( est. 91% yield ). This would be a simple reaction to give a mechanistic elucidation for those interested in organic chemistry

I am hoping to make some methyl (or ethyl) iodide for a Grignard reaction to make tertiary alcohols from ketones. However reading around about the toxicity it seems like these compounds are nasty ("highly toxic dimethyl mercury can be produced if allowed to contact mercury amalgam" for example). I do wonder if some of these fears are a little overblown but regardless, I don't have access to a fume hood so was hoping to limit my risk by conducting outside and making it on the fly for use in the Grignard. Do you have any thoughts on this?

Methyl magnesium iodide as monomethylation agent of amines. Skip trying to synth methyl amine. You and everything around you will smell like that for a long time. Use ammonia to aminate your molecule, then the Grignard to monomethylate.
